question: All right. Let's try to keep it constructive, shall we? Howard, what about you? That's not exactly what I meant by constructive, Howard. Yes, Hannah?
answer: I think maybe we're missing the point. It seems to me James' strength as a writer is that he doesn't take us by the hand. He treats us like adults. He respects us enough to forget us. That takes . . . courage .

question: Well put, Hannah. And a good note to end on, I think. Don't forget about WordFest this weekend. And remember Thanks for that. He all right?
answer: I think so. ..What about you?

question: Me? Sure. Why?
answer: Just checking.

question: I got the message you called too.
answer: Tripp!

question: How are you, Crabtree?
answer: Brimming. Say hello to my new friend, Miss Antonia. . .uh. . . . I took the liberty of inviting Antonia to tonight's festivities. You don't mind, do you. Trip? ?

question: We know each other pretty well. So where's Emily?
answer: Emily?

question: Your wife.
answer: Oh. We're picking her up. Downtown.

question: Perfect. Well then, shall we? Do you know how many times I've boarded an airplane praying someone like her would sit down beside me? Particularly while I'm on my way to Pittsburgh.
answer: Lay off Pittsburgh. It's one of the great cities.

question: If it can produce a Miss Sloviak you'll get no argument from me.
answer: She's a transvestite.

question: You're stoned.
answer: She's still a transvestite.

question: Mm.
answer: Isn't she?

question: So how's the book?
answer: It's fine. It's done. Basically. I'm just sort of. ..tinkering with it.

question: Great. I was hoping I could get a look at it sometime this weekend. Think that might be possible?
answer: I don't know. I'm sort of at a critical. . . juncture .

question: I thought you were tinkering.
answer: I just mean. . .

question: Forget I asked. I don't want to pressure you, Tripp. But... ...I get pressure. Know what I mean? Ah. ..well now. What do you suppose that would be?
answer: That would be a tuba. That perfume you're wearing, Antonia. It wouldn't happen to be Cristaile, would it?

question: Lucky guess.
answer: You didn't actually purchase this car, did you. Trip??

question: It was Jerry Nathan's. He owed me money.
answer: He owes God money. You know, he queered himself for good with Esquire.

question: He said something about being between things.
answer: Yeah, between a bookie and a pair of broken legs.

question: Hi, Tanya. This is Tanya. My wife's secretary. You're leaking, Tanya.
answer: Trip? ?

question: She left me. Crabs.
answer: Left you...? Who? Emily?

question: This morning. I found a note in the kitchen.
answer: But. ..why didn't you say something, Tripp? I mean, what are we doing here?

question: I'm sorry. It's these goddamned shoes. I don't know how anyone actually walks in these things.
answer: Practice.

question: I don't believe we've met...
answer: Antonia. Antonia Sloviak--

question: He's still barking at me. He's blind.
answer: Poe' Hush! Now stop this. Honestly.

question: I need to talk to you.
answer: That's funny. I need to talk to you, too. Perhaps you could put some of these coats in the upstairs guest room, Professor Tripp.

question: I don't believe I know where the upstairs guest room is.
answer: Well then. I'd better show you. Terry--

question: New?
answer: Walter just got it back from the framer today. You go first.

question: All right. This morning--
answer: I'm pregnant. I'm sure.

question: Well. This is...surprising. Does Walter... ?
answer: I think Walter would find this a little more than surprising.

question: Emily left me this morning.
answer: She's left before...

question: She's left the room before. She always came back.
answer: So. I guess we just divorce our spouses, marry each other, and have this baby, right? Simple.

question: Simple.
answer: Is that Cristaile?

question: Hm.
answer: My God, I wear the same scent as a transvestite. She IS a transvestite, isn't

question: If she's not now, Terry will make sure she is by the end of the evening.
answer: Has he asked to see the book yet?

question: Yes.
answer: And? Are you going to tell him?

question: No. Maybe. I don't know. I don't know what I'm going to do.
answer: Neither do 1.

question: Sara, my arm. I'm stuck, honey.
answer: I guess you're going to have to chew it off then.

question: I could swear I had a '63 Chateau Latour in here. You haven't seen it, have you?
answer: I doubt I'd recognize a '63 Chateau Latour if I was sitting on it.

question: You'd recognize it if you tasted it.
answer: I doubt it, darling.

question: Well, Q certainly will. And, given that he will be addressing 500 people in little over an hour...
answer: You want to keep him happy.

question: James?
answer: It's fake. It was my mother's. She won it in a penny arcade in Baltimore when she was in Catholic school.

question: It's very convincing.
answer: It used to shoot these little paper caps, but they don't make them anymore. The caps. It's just. ..for good luck. Some people carry rabbits' feet...

question: ...You carry firearms.
answer: No, thank you. I don't like to lose control of my emotions. I'm not supposed to be here, in case you were wondering. I crashed. I mean, not intentionally...

question: Are you and Hannah seeing each other, James ?
answer: No! What gave you that idea?

question: Relax, James. I'm not her father. I just rent her a room.
answer: She likes old movies like I do, that's ail. Besides, she doesn't really know me. She thinks she does, but she doesn't. Maybe it's because she's Mormon and I'm Catholic.

question: Maybe it's because she's beautiful and she knows it and try as she might to not let that screw her up, it's inevitable that it will in some way.
answer: You're not like my other teachers, Professor Tripp.

question: You're not like my other students, James. So what was the movie you two saw?
answer: Huh? Oh. Son or Fury. With Tyrone Power and Frances Farmer.

question: She went crazy, Frances Farmer.
answer: So did Gene Tierney. She's in it too.

question: Sounds like a good one.
answer: It's not bad.

question: Listen, James, about this afternoon. In workshop. I'm sorry. I think I let things get a bit out of control.
answer: They really hated it. I think they hated it more than any of the other ones.

question: Well...
answer: It doesn't matter. It only took me an hour to write.

question: Really? That's remarkable.
answer: I have trouble sleeping. While I'm lying in bed I figure them out. The stories.

question: You cold, James?
answer: A little.

question: So what are you doing out here?
answer: It's colder in there. -

question: You're right.
answer: Actually, I saw the greenhouse. So I thought ...I thought I'd come out here and take a look at it. You don't see one of those every day. It looks like heaven...

question: Heaven?
answer: I saw a movie once. Part of it took place in heaven. Everyone wore white and lived in crystal houses. Like that. At least that's the way I remember it... I should be going.

question: James. Don't leave just yet. There's something I think you ought to see.
answer: I'll miss my bus.

question: Oh, James is amazing. He knows all the movie suicides. Go ahead, James. Tell them who else.
answer: There's so many...

question: Just a few then. The big ones.
answer: Pier Angeli, 1971 or '72, also pills. Charles Boyer, 1978, pills again. Charles Butterworth, 1946, I think. In a car. Supposedly it was an accident, but, you know. . . He was distraught. Dorothy Dandridge, she took pills in, like, 1965. Albert Dekker, 1968, he hung himself. He wrote his suicide note in lipstick on his stomach. Alan Ladd, '64, more pills, Carole Landis, pills again, I forget when. George Reeves, Superman on TV, shot himself. Jean Seberg/ pills of course, 1979. Everett Sioane-- he was good--pills. Margaret Sullavan, pills, Lupe Velez, a lot of pills. Gig Young. He shot himself and his wife in 1978. There are more but I don't know if you would have heard of them. Ross Alexander? Clara Blandick? Maggie McNamara? Gia Scaia?

question: You did them alphabetically.
answer: That's just how my brain works, I guess.

question: Fascinating. Listen, why don't you come out with us after the lecture. There's a place on the Hill I always get Trip to take me.
answer: Actually. ..I just want to go home.

question: Oh, don't be silly. No one your age just wants to go home. Besides, faculty will be present. Just think of it as a field trip.
answer: Is that really it?

question: Is that really it?
answer: That's really it.

question: The one she wore on her wedding day?
answer: So I'm told. Go ahead.

question: Really?
answer: Really.

question: They're glass. The buttons.
answer: Like the lady herself.

question: She was small. Most people don't know that. The shoulders are small. It looks so perfect. I bet it's the only time she wore it. That day. She must've felt so ...happy. It's feels unreal, like butterfly wings or... something. It must've cost Dr. Gaskell a lot.
answer: I guess. Walter never tells Sara the truth about how much he pays for these things.

question: You're really good friends with the Chancellor, aren't you?
answer: Pretty good. I'm friends with Dr. Gaskell, too.

question: I guess you must be, if you know the combination to his closet and he doesn't mind your being here in their bedroom like this.
answer: Right. We, better skedaddle. Close that closet-- James? You ail right?

question: I'm sorry. Professor Tripp. Maybe it's seeing that jacket that belonged to her. It just looks...really lonely. Hanging there. In a closet. Maybe I'm just a little sad.
answer: Maybe. I'm feeling a little sad myself tonight.

question: You mean, with your wife leaving you and ail? Hannah mentioned something about it. About a note.
answer: Yes. Well. It's complicated, James. I think we should go now. Okay. Easy now. Eee-zy. . . . Jesus! Get off of me, you son-of-a-bitch! Shit, James. You shoe Dr. Gaskell's dog.

question: I had to. Didn't I?
answer: Couldn't you've just pulled him off me?

question: No! He was crazy. I didn't-he looked-- 1 thought --
answer: Okay, okay. Take it easy. Don't freak out on me.

question: Do you have a mirror? It's the best way to see if someone's breathing.
answer: He's dead, James. Believe me, I know a dead dog when I see one.

question: What are we going to do?
answer: First you're going to give me that little cap gun of yours.

question: Professor Tripp? Can I ask you a question?
answer: Yea, James.

question: What are we going to do with...
answer: I don't know. I'm still trying to figure out how to tell the Chancellor I murdered her husband's dog.

question: You?
answer: Trust me, James, when the family pet's been assassinated, the owner doesn't want to hear one of her students was the triggerman.

question: Does she want to hear it was one of her professors?
answer: I've got tenure. Okay.

question: He's still a little warm. Yuck. That's a. big trunk. It fits a tuba, a suitcase, a dead dog, and a garment bag almost perfectly.
answer: That's just what they used to say in the ads. Come on, Crabtree, I know you're holding...

question: Whose tuba is that anyway?
answer: Miss Sloviak's.

question: Can I ask you something about her?
answer: She is. Ah. Here we go...

question: Oh. So. Is--is your friend Crabtree-- is he-- gay?
answer: Most of the time he is, James. Some of the time he isn't. Now what do we have here? Looks like ...our old friend Mr. Codeine. That should take the pinch out of my ankle. Have one.

question: No thanks. I'm fine without them.
answer: Right. That's why you were standing in the Chancellor's back yard twirling that little cap gun of yours tonight. You're fine, all right, you're fit as a fucking fiddle. I'm sorry, James. I'm sorry I said that. How 'bout we try that again.

question: You had another one, didn't you? You have to see a doctor, Grady. First thing Monday morning. All right?
answer: Is the thing-is it over?

question: Almost. Wane to sit up? What's the matter?
answer: Nothing. I think I twisted my-- I have to tell you something. Something.. .hard.

question: Then stand up. I'm too old for all this roiling around on the floor.
answer: Well...

question: Don't. I know what you're going to say.
answer: No, really, Sara, I don't think you--

question: You love Emily. I know that. And you need to stay with her.
answer: I don't think I really have a choice in, that. Emily left me.

question: She'll come back. That's why I'm going to. ..to not have this baby.
answer: Not have it.

question: No. There's no way. I mean, don't you think there's no way?
answer: Well, no, I don't see any way. And I know how hard it is for you to-- to lose this chance.

question: No you don't. And fuck you for saying you do. And fuck you for "saying. . . ...for saying there's just no way. Because there could be a way, Grady. He must be finishing. We should go. Who's gun is that?
answer: It's-it's a souvenir. Of Baltimore.

question: Heavy. Smells like gunpowder.
answer: Caps.

question: Pow.
answer: You got me.

question: I love you, Grady.
answer: I love you, too.

question: I need a ride.
answer: I'm your man. There's an explanation.

question: Couldn't he have just thrown a shoe at the poor thing?
answer: James is. ..I don't know...

question: Disturbed. And when your friend CRABTREE gets done with him, he's going to be even more disturbed.
answer: I'm not sure that's possible.

question: Sure it is.
answer: Listen, Antonia--

question: Tony. Now that I'm home.
answer: Tony. I'm sorry if things didn't work out so well for you tonight. With Terry.

question: Forget it. I should've known better. Your friend is just, I don't know, into collecting weird tricks. Mind?
answer: He's writing his name in water.

question: What's that?
answer: Like most editors, he really wants to be a writer, but he's too busy living a novel to bother writing one.

question: That sounds like a fancy excuse for being a shit.
answer: He'd call it habit. But now. ..I get the feeling he's going through the motions a bit.

question: You mean because his career's ruined and all?
answer: Jesus. Is that what he told you?

question: He said he hasn't had a success in ten years and everyone in New York thinks he's kind of .a. . . ...loser. But I'm sure your book is so good that he'll be able to keep his job. Turn here.
answer: That'' s nice. All we have is a Japanese beetle trap.

question: It's a bathtub. What she's standing under. There's Pop. Let me see it. The gun. Figures. It's like the kind of gun Bette Davis would carry. In a little beaded purse?
answer: I'd better go. I think I may have to rescue James Leer.

question: You know, Grady, if I were you. I'd think about going home. You look like you need a little rescuing yourself.
answer: As a whistle. Double Dickel on the rocks. Is that just beer?

question: As a whistle. Double Dickel on the rocks. Is that just beer?
answer: Primarily. Although I gather you two staged a little raid on the CRABTREE pharmacopoeia. You missed a few bottles, by the way.

question: I'm sure. Where is everyone?
answer: Sara and Walter declined. Guess they wanted to go home and curl up on the couch with the dog.

question: Jesus. He's out.
answer: He has a book.

question: I know. He started it Fall semester.
answer: He finished it Winter Break. So. Is he any good?

question: No. Not yet he isn't.
answer: Well, I'm going to read it anyway.

question: Come on. Crabs. Don't do this. He's . one o my students, for Christ sake. I'm not even sure if he's-
answer: He is. Take my word for it.

question: I think it's more complicated than that. Besides, he's a little...scattered. He almost ...did something stupid tonight. At least, I think so. Anyway, he doesn't need sexual confusion thrown into the stew right now.
answer: On the contrary, it 'could be just the ticket.

question: Thanks.
answer: No sexual confusion there, eh, Professor?

question: Shut up and drink.
answer: Oh my goodness. Do you see what I see?

question: President of the James Brown Hair Club For Men. He's a boxer. A flyweight.
answer: Huh uh. A jockey. His name's, um, Curtis.. .Curtis Hardapple.

question: Not Curtis.
answer: Vernon, then. Vernon Hardapple. The scar's are from a--from a horse. He fell during a race and got trampled.

question: And now he's addicted to painkillers.
answer: He can't piss standing up anymore.

question: He lives with his mother.
answer: And he had a younger brother who . . .was . . . a. . .

question: Groom. Named Claudell. And his mother blames Vernon for his death.
answer: Because. . .because. . .

question: He heard everything we were saying.
answer: Come on. Teach. I want you to dance with me. I've been re-reading Arsonist's Daughter. It's so beautiful, Grady. So natural. It's like ail your sentences always existed, just waiting around in Style Heaven, or wherever, for you to fetch them down.

question: I thank you.
answer: And I love the inscription you wrote to me. Only I'm not quite the downy innocent you think I am.

question: I hope that isn't true. We need all the downy innocents we can get.
answer: So what are you going to do?

question: Do?
answer: I just mean, I--I guess Emily isn't going to be there when you get home.

question: Are you holding me up or am I dragging you down?
answer: Shush.

question: Look, Hannah. When you get him home ...make sure he's ail right. Before you leave. Okay?
answer: I would if I knew where I was taking him.

question: Hannah, are you telling me you don't know where James Leer lives?
answer: Some apartment somewhere. But I've never seen it.

question: That strikes me as odd.
answer: James is odd. I know he has an aunt in Sewickley Heights. I dropped him there once, but... Come to think of it, it-wasn't even his Aunt's house. He said she worked there. Or something. I don't remember.

question: Excuse me? It's mine. You must be mistaken. Go home to your mother, Vernon. All right, what's the matter? Christ, Crabs, what do you expect me to do? The kid's practically in a coma.
answer: Tripp.

question: Yes.
answer: Hit your brakes.

question: What's this guy's problem?
answer: Just go around him.

question: Shit.
answer: Back up. Go out the other way.

question: Now what? I just had my car jumped on. Wait here. I'll be right back.
answer: Where would we go?

question: I hope it wasn't my fault.
answer: No. I guess you're here for the backpack.

question: Oh.. .yeah.
answer: I saw the manuscript inside. So when you showed up, I figured. . . Is it good?

question: I don't know. It might be...
answer: Say, Professor Tripp, is ail that stuff true about Errol Flynn? How he used to put coke on his dick. To make himself, you know, like, last longer?

question: Christ, Traxler. How the hell should I know?
answer: Well, jeez, you're reading his biography, aren't you?

question: Oh, right. Yeah, that's true. He used to rub ail kinds of things on it. Paprika. Ground lamb.
answer: Sick. Wow, check out that greenhouse. Is that your wife?

question: No, my wife's out of town. Her husband.
answer: What exactly are we doing here, Professor Tripp?

question: Taking the long way home.
answer: Thank you.

question: You're welcome. James I I'm okay. I just lost my balance.
answer: I put you on the floor.

question: Oh.
answer: I thought you might--l don't know-- swallow your tongue or something. I guess you really miss her, huh?

question: Huh? Oh, no. This isn't Emily's. I just write in it.
answer: I guess there's probably a story behind that.

question: There is, but it's not that interesting.
answer: Want me to get that?

question: Sure.
answer: He didn't give his name.

question: Who?
answer: The guy on the phone.

question: What'd he say?
answer: He wanted to know if a GRADY Trip? lived here and drove a dark maroon 1966 Ford Galaxie 500 with black interior.

question: What'd you tell him?
answer: Yes.

question: Good, James. If the Zodiac killer calls, be sure to mention the back door pops open with a couple hard shakes to the right.
answer: I thought maybe you'd won a radio contest or something. Is that single-spaced?

question: Afraid so.
answer: That's a big book you're writing.

question: I think it's sort of writing itself at this point.
answer: Wow, Hannah always swore you were working, but--

question: But . . . ?
answer: Nothing, it's just that,, well, it's been awhile since Arsonist's Daughter, and some people--some of the kids in workshop--thought maybe you were...

question: Washed up?
answer: Blocked.

question: Ah. I don't believe in writer's block.
answer: No kidding.

question: If-you 're planning on staying for breakfast, I'd put on something a little less comfortable if I were you.
answer: Professor Tripp?

question: Hm.
answer: How did I get here last night?

question: No one seems to know where you live, James. Hannah thought you'd like my couch.
answer: And ...and before that. Did I do anything? Anything bad?

question: Well, James, you did shoot the Head of the English Department's dog and steal his most prized piece of memorabilia. Do yourself a favor, James ...Hide.
answer: Good morning... Professor Tripp? Sorry to bother you, sir, but I understand you attended an event at Sara and Walter Gaskell's house last night and were one of the last to leave... ...was just wondering if maybe you saw anyone. Someone you didn't know. Who seemed out of place. Suspicious maybe...

question: Well, there's always people you don't know at these things, but I can't say there was anybody particularly suspicious. ..Wait. There was one guy. Tiny fella. Claimed to be a jockey.
answer: A jockey? You mean, like--

question: Horses, right. Vernon something... Hardpple
answer: Hardapple?

question: I could be wrong. What happened anyway?
answer: Huh? Oh, someone pulled a B&E on Dr. Gaskell's closet. And the dog's missing.

question: That's weird.
answer: We figure the perpetrator let him out. He's blind and we figure he just wandered off and got run over.

question: The perpetrator.
answer: No, the dog.

question: Just kidding.
answer: One other thing. About this kid, this student of yours- Leer--James Leer. You wouldn't know how I could get in touch with him, would you?

question: I might have his number on campus.
answer: That's all right. We'll find him.

question: Could you hold on a minute, honey? How 'bout we get the hell out of here? You start her up.
answer: How's that?

question: Well done, James.
answer: You're bleeding. Professor Tripp.

question: Where exactly do you live, James? Apparently not even Hannah Green has a clue as to the location of your apartment.
answer: I got kicked out. Well, not exactly kicked out. I was asked to leave.

question: I guess there's probably a story behind that.
answer: There is, but it's not that interesting.

question: So where have you been staying?
answer: The bus station. It's not -so bad. I know the night janitor. And there's a broken locker I can put my stuff.

question: But James. I mean. ..How long?
answer: A couple weeks. That's why... that's why I had the gun. For protection.

question: Jesus, James, you should've told someone.
answer: Who?

question: I don't know... Me.
answer: Nice. Isn't this...?

question: Hm. You better ease off that stuff, James. It's pretty acidic.
answer: I can't help myself. I don't know what's the matter with me.

question: Shit, James, you're hungover. What do you think's the matter with you? Totally. I'm sorry. A lot was happening this morning. Can you talk?
answer: Walter's on campus, being the good soldier for WordFest. But he's a basket case. Someone stole Marilyn's jacket last night. And Poe's missing, too.

question: I-heard.
answer: You heard? How?

question: A twelve-year-old policeman came by the house this morning.
answer: Did you confess? Your fingerprints were all over the bedroom.

question: Really? That was fast.
answer: I'm kidding. Hello?

question: Oh. Right. Ha. Listen, about last night. There is something I need to tell...
answer: Are you limping? Why are you limping?

question: Hub? Oh, well, that's part of what I need to .
answer: Did you pass out again, Grady? Did you fall somewhere?

question: No. I mean. Well, actually, yes. Sort of. I don't remember. Listen, Sara, I have to tell you something.
answer: All right. Gee, Grady, that sounded so heartfelt. I don't know whether to swoon or smirk.

question: Really, Sara, I...
answer: I believe you. I believe you want to be with me. But this is not just about me anymore.

question: I know that. I know what's at stake here...
answer: No, I don't think you do. And besides... I haven't decided yet.

question: About the baby.
answer: That ...and you. I'm not going to draw the map for you on this one, Grady. Times like these you have to do your own navigating. Who's that sitting in your car?

question: James Leer.
answer: What's he doing out there?

question: I'm sort of helping him work through some issues.
answer: Isn't he lucky.

question: She seemed to take it pretty well.
answer: Yeah, well, actually. . . Don't be proud, James. We're in Sewickley Heights. We could find you a nice golf course to barf on.

question: No.
answer: Your aunt ?

question: Humboldt County?
answer: Maybe...

question: It's my father. He gets it from his doctor.
answer: Glaucoma?

question: Colon cancer.
answer: Jesus, James. Wow. Where's that?

question: Carvel.
answer: Carvel? Where's Carvel?

question: Outside Scranton.
answer: I never heard of it.

question: It's a hellhole. Three motels and a mannequin factory. My dad worked there for thirty-five years.
answer: Your father worked in a mannequin factory?

question: Seitz Plastics. That's where he met my morn. She was a fry cook in the cafeteria. Before that, she'd been a dancer.
answer: What kind of dancer? .

question: Whatever kind they wanted her to be.
answer: James Leer, are you telling me your mother was a stripper?

question: I'm telling you what I was told by my uncle. And he should know. He ran half a dozen men's clubs in Baltimore before he skipped town on a bad debt.
answer: Didn't you say your Mom went to Catholic school?

question: When we fall, we fall hard.
answer: Amazing.

question: Maybe I just needed the moment to present itself. This is so nice. It's like where Andy Hardy would live. What's it called again?
answer: Kinship.

question: Kinship. And what's here?
answer: Unless I miss my bet...my wife.

question: The one that left you?
answer: That's right. That one.

question: Someone jumped on your car with their butt ..-
answer: How can you tell?

question: You can see the outline of a butt.
answer: Smoke the rest of that joint, James, and you can start on the box.

question: Maybe she didn't come here.
answer: She came here. We'll just wait. In the meantime, I need you to shimmy through. Relax. Emily hasn't carried a house key since she was twelve years old. And your hips are as slim as hers.

question: It's not that. It just reminded me of-- you know-of what's in the car. In the trunk.
answer: Oh. Right. Well, let's try not to think about that.

question: It feels really... good. ..here.
answer: I know. It's the house you want to wake up in on Christmas morning. Make yourself at home. I'll be right back. Yes, I' m looking for the Chancellor... I don't know. She should be in the main hall ...Thank you. cups a hand over his ear. Sara? Hi. It's Grady.

question: I know. It's the house you want to wake up in on Christmas morning. Make yourself at home. I'll be right back. Yes, I' m looking for the Chancellor... I don't know. She should be in the main hall ...Thank you. cups a hand over his ear. Sara? Hi. It's Grady.
answer: Where are you, Grady? An elevator?

question: I'm in Kinship. Listen, Sara, there's some things we need to talk about...
answer: You're in Kinship?

question: Yes. But that's not why I called...
answer: With Emily?

question: What? No'. There's no one here. I'm just ...just....
answer: Just what? Doing a little dusting?

question: James! For Christ sake, will you turn that thing down!
answer: James? He's still with you?

question: Look, Sara. ..I'm not here. ..I'm not here to
answer: Are you there to not reconcile with her?

question: No. Sara, you don't understand...
answer: Trust me, I understand. I just want to say something to you, Grady.

question: Yea?
answer: How you choose to live your own life is your business. But you be careful with that boy, Grady. With James. He belongs to somebody else.

question: Mom. Dad.
answer: Well, it's infected, I can tell you that. I'm just going to clean it up a bit. It's up to you to-find someone who knows what they're doing. Here. Put your foot up. So he's one of your students, this boy?

question: Yes. He's a good kid. Maybe a little messed up.
answer: Well, I'm sure with the proper guidance he'll be fine.

question: What made you pull out that old thing?
answer: I was thinking of you.

question: And?
answer: It's no Arsonist's Daughter, but I guess you know that. It's a young man's book. It got me remembering how it felt to be young.

question: Maybe I should read it.
answer: Oh, I don't think there's any danger of you aging prematurely, Grady.

question: Where's Emily, Hank?
answer: I 'don't know if she'd want me to tell you that, Grady.

question: I'm not going to stalk her. Hank. I just. ..want to know where I stand.
answer: Where you stand?

question: l-just want to say I'm sorry.
answer: She's in Philadelphia seeing Linda Aahby. The neurologist.

question: Neurologist? Why? What's wrong?
answer: Nothing's wrong. They went to Wellesley together.

question: Oh. Right. Linda ...I haven't been doing a lot of sleeping lately. My editor's in town and I have the book to finish and--
answer: Ah, right. The book.

question: Listen, Hank, I'm sorry about ail this. I didn't come here to upset you and Irene. I want you to know that.
answer: Why did you come here, Grady?

question: I -just wanted to see her, I guess-- Emily. And to see you too-you and Irene. And to let everyone know that, even though it may be difficult to comprehend now, this-everything that's happening-it's not forever. It doesn't mean "Goodbye."
answer: Give me a break, Grady. You're done.

question: I'm having a really good time, Professor Tripp.
answer: I'm really happy for you, James. But do me a favor, will you? Lay off my dope. That stuff's not for amateurs.

question: I just wanted a little sip.
answer: I just wanted a little sip? Tell me, James, exactly what point was it that you turned into Serpent Boy?

question: Probably about the time you gave me the codeine pills last night.
answer: Jesus... Look, James, you appear to possess-like many an aspiring writer before you, by the way-a rather ardent affinity for the stuff of which dreams are made. However, I 'think it's best if, for the moment at least ...we abstain.

question: You're mad at me, aren't you?
answer: What?

question: You're mad because I shot your girlfriend's dog.
answer: It wasn't her dog. It's her husband's-- Who said anything about girlfriend? Okay, James, I wish you hadn't shot my girlfriend's dog. Even though Poe and I weren't exactly what you'd call simpatico, that's no reason for him to take two in the chest. Still, the fact remains that I'm the one who took you up into the Chancellor's bedroom. I'm the one who has to take the blame. I- don't know what the hell I was thinking.

question: Sure you do. You were thinking
answer: Thanks for the halo, James, but I've . never done that much thinking ahead in my" life-ever.

question: So, why did you take me up there?
answer: I -don' t know, James . I don' t know why I do half the things I do. Who does? Why do you wear that coat?

question: It's warm.
answer: James, fall semester, first day of class, it was 95 degrees and you were wearing the coat. That's why they all give you such a hard time in workshop.

question: Because of my coat?
answer: Because you act like a goddamn spook all the time. Not to mention the fact that every last one of them is jealous of you.

question: Jealous? Of me?
answer: Not you. Your talent.

question: You're lying.
answer: The hell I am.

question: Yes you are. My stuff stinks. I know it. You said so yourself.
answer: I never said that.

question: Yes you did. Last night. To your friend Crabtree. "Is he any good?" he said. And you said
answer: I didn't mean it that way.

question: It's okay, Professor Tripp. Carrie, Howard, the others--they 're right. My stories are annoying. They go on and on and on, and the longer they go on the more annoying they become, until finally you just want to grab something heavy and--
answer: Shut up, James. You're annoying. Carrie and Howard don't know what the fuck they're talking about, okay? The entire class combined- including the lovely Hannah Green-has about one tenth of one percent the talent you have, okay?

question: But, last night...
answer: Who cares what-. I said last night, James I I was drunk, I was stoned. I'd been bitten by a dog. My wife had left me. How 'bout cutting me some slack?

question: I'm sorry.
answer: And don't be so goddamn sensitive. Who cares what anybody thinks anyway? You want to .be a good writer? You want to be-a great writer? Then stop giving a damn what other people think. Most of them haven't thought in .years. Let me spell it .out for you, James. Books don't mean anything. Not to anybody. Not anymore.

question: Arsonist's Daughter meant something. I mean it. It means something to me. It's one of the reasons I came to school here. To be in your class. To be taught by you. It's one of the reasons I wanted to become a writer.
answer: Well, for that, if nothing else, James, I'm sorry.

question: You coming?
answer: In a minute. Get us a table. C-a-r-v-e-I. That's right, Carvel. Yes, I'm sure. It's outside Scranton. You have no listing. Okay, well, lady-- at this very moment, as we speak, I'm looking of a resident of Carvel, Pennsylvania. I think he'd be pretty interested to learn that the good people of Bell Atlantic have misplaced his entire hometown. It's not like I'm making this up as I go along--

question: Want a bite?
answer: No thanks.

question: That's why you're having them. Your spells.
answer: Spells? Jesus, James, you make it sound like we're in a Tennessee Williams play. I don't have spells.

question: What would you call them then?
answer: I don't know. ...'Episodes.'

question: It's because you don't eat.
answer: I eat.

question: When?
answer: When nobody's looking.

question: I just worry about you, that's all.
answer: You just worry about yourself, James. Okay?

question: Okay.
answer: Nowhere. You just sit here and... eat. Grady. Looks like I've dashed a-wonderful evening.

question: Nowhere. You just sit here and... eat. Grady. Looks like I've dashed a-wonderful evening.
answer: Hardly. Otherwise we would've been here earlier.

question: Ah. Well, that's ail right. James and I 'had a little dinner.
answer: Well, certainly we'll reimburse you.

question: That's not necessary. I just felt. ..it might be good for James to be with his family this weekend.
answer: Well, of course, we can understand that.

question: Well. Let me go get him.
answer: I'm not going with them..

question: James. Listen. Things-things are a little weird with me right now and I-- well--I have enough blame to shoulder these days without having to take the blame if something bad happened to you. And if you hang around me long enough, something bad is going to happen, trust me. That's why I need you to go home. Understand?
answer: I'm not going, with them.

question: James, like it or not, they're your parents.
answer: Parents? They're not my parents. They're my grandparents. My parents are dead. I swear. My father had his own airplane he used to fly up to Quebec. One Christmas, he and my mom were flying up to our house in the Laurentians when the plane went down. It was in the newspaper. I 'swear. My father was a senior vice president at Dravo. My mother was a socialite. Her maiden name was Guggenheim.

question: I remember that. Five or six years ago.
answer: Six. Their plane went down right outside Scranton.

question: Near Carvel?
answer: I'm sorry about all that. I just-I don't like to talk about my family. They treat me like a freak.

question: James, come on. That man is obviously your father. You look just like him.
answer: There's a reason for that.

question: Get out of here.
answer: That's why she hates me. That's why she makes me sleep in the basement.

question: In the crawl space, with the rats and the casks of Amontillado. Come on. Up.
answer: I swear.

question: Take care of him. Hey! Crabtree. Hey.
answer: Grady! I know I shouldn't have, but there it was, just sort of lying out, and I couldn't resist and-and--I suck.

question: No, it's okay. I just can't believe I left it out in the open like that. CRABTREE hasn't been in here, has he? Poking around?
answer: I don't know--maybe- I don't think so.

question: Listen, Hannah. You don't remember where that aunt worked, do you? James' aunt.
answer: He shot the Chancellor's dog, didn't he? The blind one.

question: Actually, He's not the Chancellor' s--What?
answer: At first the police thought he just ran away, but this afternoon Dr. Gaskell found some blood spots on the carpet -

question: Jesus.
answer: CRABTREE said it sounded like something James would be messed up in.

question: Crabtree? He doesn't even know James.
answer: Who does?

question: Listen, Hannah, I'm flattered, really, but right now I--
answer: Tripp, where the hell. . .

question: You stay there.
answer: What? Ohhhh. Is that... it? Honestly, Tripp. Do you actually think I would sneak in here and read your book without asking you?

question: Gee, I don't know. Crabs. I don't seem to remember you actually asking me if you could invite 200 people over to trash my living room.
answer: Sometimes we have to improvise.

question: Think, Hannah. Does James have any friends. I mean, besides you and. ..me?
answer: James? My James? What's happened?

question: Nothing, he's just been sort of, I don't know.. .kidnapped.
answer: Kidnapped? By who?

question: His parents.
answer: Good God. Let's go rescue him.

question: Good idea. Crabs. Only one problem. I don't know where they live.
answer: Ah. Wait a minute. The university must know where he lives.

question: It's a little late to call Admissions.
answer: Is it a little late to call the Chancellor?

question: You know--based on what I've read-- this is a very exciting piece of material, this Big Parade.
answer: Love. It's Love facade--and what do you mean 'based on what you've read'? You skimmed two chapters at 80 miles an hour while gargling methamphetamines.

question: I've been doing this a long time, Tripp. I feel this kid in my bones.
answer: Only in your bones?

question: No. I think I might be right. I've felt it before...
answer: How bad is it for you?

question: Bad enough. And God knows I don't exactly fit the new corporate profile.
answer: Which is?

question: Competence.
answer: What's to tell?

question: Plenty, I'm sure. But, for what it's worth... ...I like her.
answer: Me too. This is it.

question: Jesus. There must be two dozen windows on . that thing. How are we-supposed to find his?
answer: I told you. They keep him chained in the basement. Come on.

question: Ah, wear whatever you want.
answer: So modest.

question: So sensitive.
answer: Oh, come on, Tripp. Cut the kid some slack.

question: It's just ail that crap he spins out. Just once I'd like to know if the little bastard is telling the truth.
answer: The-truth. I know that's always been real important to you. Key, check this out... Finally, the door opened. It-was a shock to

question: Yes? 'His heart...'
answer: 'His heart, once capable of inspiring others so completely, could no longer inspire so much as itself. It beat now only out of habit. It beat now only because it could. '

question: 'His heart, once capable of inspiring others so completely, could no longer inspire so much as itself. It beat now only out of habit. It beat now only because it could. '
answer: I'm ready... You all right, Professor Tripp?

question: He's great. Come on, let's blow before ol' Gran decides to boil your bones for breakfast.
answer: Oh, well, that's just it. She's been coming down here, every half hour or so, to, sort of, check on me. If I'm not here, she might ...call the police or.. .something.

question: Hhhuh. So we decoy her. Stick a couple pillows and one of your teddy bears under the spread and she won't know the difference.
answer: Yeah. Like in Against All Flags. Only they use a couple big hams.

question: No. I've got something better than a teddy bear. Sweet dreams, Jimmy.
answer: Things must've picked up after we left.

question: Crabtree.
answer: Ye-es?

question: Nothing. How are you--is it Joe?
answer: Jeff. Sorry. I didn't even know this was your house until about an hour ago.

question: Don't sweat it. Well. 'Night, Jeff.
answer: Oh, Professor Tripp? You know, last semester, what I said that time in office hours-I hope there's no hard feelings.

question: No...
answer: I mean, I was breaking up with this girl at the time and my car was ail fucked up and-- well--I was pretty bent in general.

question: It's cool, Jeff. Really.
answer: I just want you to know that's why I dropped your class and said all that shit about the university stealing my money and you being a pseudo-Faulknerian nobody.

question: Walter?
answer: Yes?

question: It's Grady, Walter.
answer: Grady?

question: GRADY Tripp. English Department.
answer: I know it's you, Grady, I just... Christ, Grady, do you know what time it -is?

question: I have ...eight-fifteen. That's not right, is it?
answer: It's three-thirty, Grady.

question: This is important.
answer: Oh? What is it, Grady?

question: I'm in love with your wife.
answer: Excuse me?

question: Sara. I'm in love with her.
answer: Are you drinking. Professor Tripp? Right now.

question: No.
answer: Nevertheless, I'd like to see you in my office Monday morning.

question: Sara.
answer: I tried to call, but apparently there's something wrong...

question: Oh?
answer: It seems one of our students is - missing and his parents found a dead dog in his bed.

question: I'm sorry, Sara. I've been trying to tell you. It's all my-
answer: I'm not very happy with you right now, Grady. But more importantly, Walter's not very happy and he's gotten the police involved. They seem to think James Leer is somehow responsible for all of this. You wouldn't happen to know where James is, would you, Grady?

question: Inside.
answer: And the jacket?

question: Over there. In the backseat of the...
answer: Grady.

question: Honestly. Someone stole my car. I parked it right there last night.
answer: Are you sure you parked it there?

question: Of course, I'm sure. Ah, Christ, the puberty police are back.
answer: I'll deal with this. You dig up James.

question: Shut up, James.
answer: So what's the problem?

question: There is no problem. Did I say there was a problem?
answer: Who's that?

question: Who do you think it is?
answer: The Chancellor's here? Now?

question: Great. Between you and Officer Pupcik out there he can be the next Jean Genet. It's been awhile since somebody wrote a good book in jail. Don't worry, James, I'll figure something out.
answer: I'm not worried. You're not worried, are you. Professor Tripp?

question: I'm a little worried, James.
answer: Don't be. I don't care if they expel me. I probably should be expelled.

question: Well, let's see if we can keep that from happening.
answer: Professor Tripp...?

question: Yes, James.
answer: Even if I end up going to jail....

question: This is not what the university has in mind when it promises a liberal education, Grady.
answer: Would Walter really press charges?

question: It's within the realm. He takes his souvenirs pretty seriously. And he was just a wee bit prickly this morning.
answer: I think I might have.

question: And what do you think you might have said?
answer: I think I might've said I was in love with you.

question: He told me.
answer: And what did you say?

question: So- what do we do now? ,
answer: Find the jacket.

question: Oh' huh. Exactly how do we do that?
answer: First I see if Hannah will let me borrow her car.

question: Hey, Jeff. If you're really interested in discussing that business with the tango, try the guy at the end of the hall. He cribbed that from Borges.
answer: It beats 'What's your major?'

question: Right. Anyway, I was wondering if I could borrow your car. Mine's sort of out of commission.
answer: Sure. The keys are on the dresser next to. ..to your book. I uh, I didn't finish, I ...fell asleep.

question: That good, hub?
answer: No, it's not that, it's... It's just that, you know, I was thinking about how, in class, you're always telling us '-that writers make choices--at least the good ones. And, don't get me wrong. I'm not saying the book isn't really great-I mean, really great- but at times it's, well, very detailed, you know, with the genealogies of everyone's horses and ail the dental records and so on-and I don't know, maybe I'm wrong, but it sort of reads, in places, like, well, actually, like... ...you didn't make any choices at all. And I was wondering if it might not be different if, maybe, when you wrote, you weren't always ...under the influence.

question: Hh huh. Well, thanks for the thought, but, as shocking as this may sound, I'm not the first writer to sip a little weed. And furthermore, it might interest you to know that one book I wrote, as you say, 'under the influence, ' happened to win a little something called the PEN award which, by the way, I accepted 'under the influence. '
answer: Want some help with that?

question: Don't touch it.
answer: Let me get this straight. Jerry Nathan owes you money. So, as collateral, he gives you his car.

question: Only now I'm starting to think the car wasn't exactly Jerry's to give.
answer: So whose car is it?

question: My guess-Vernon Hardapple.
answer: The hood jumper?

question: He said a few things that lead me to believe the car's his.
answer: Such as.

question: 'That's my car, motherfucker.'
answer: Hh hub. So. We find Vernon, we find the car. We find the car...

question: ...we find the jacket.
answer: There's only one problem, Tripp. We don't know his real name. We just made it up. In fact, we made the whole guy up.

question: No wonder he screwed us over.
answer: Christ, Tripp. How did you know?

question: Call it a hunch.
answer: I'd call it genius.

question: It's good to know I'm still talented at something. Keep the motor running.
answer: What the hell...

question: I never forget an Oola. Vernon.
answer: Move away, cupcake. He's got a gun.

question: Who's got a gun?
answer: You've got a gun, motherfucker. Drop it!

question: No! Don't shoot! He's just a lousy driver. Oh... my... God!
answer: Naturally you have copies.

question: I have an alternate version of the first chapter.
answer: You'll be all right then. Look at Carlyle, when he lost his luggage.

question: That was MacCaulay.
answer: Or Hemingway, when Hadley lost all those stories.

question: He was never able to reproduce them.
answer: Bad examples. Look, Tripp, I don't want to depreciate the loss here, but perhaps--in a sense- this-- is for the best.

question: Kind of a sign, you're saying.
answer: In a sense.

question: And you're saying it's some kind of sign? What the fuck's the matter with you?
answer: I'm just saying that sometimes, subconsciously, a person will put themselves in a situation-perhaps even create that situation- in order to have an arena in which to work out an unresolved issue. It's a covert way, if you will, of addressing a problem.

question: I'll tell you the problem. You behind the wheel. There's your fucking problem.
answer: That's pretty simplistic, don't you think?

question: Hey, pal, you don't start doing crazy eights in the middle of the street none of this happens.
answer: Excuse me. Did you, or did you not, have a gun to his head?

question: Yeah, but you gotta know what it's about, right? I mean, if you didn't know what it was about, why were you writing it?
answer: I couldn't stop. Hey, Vernon. Can I ask you a question?

question: Shoot.
answer: Boy or girl?

question: As long as it looks like her, I don't care. You know what I'm saying?
answer: Right. Well, thanks. For the lift.

question: No sweat. Only do me a favor?
answer: Sure.

question: You mind explaining what you just did?
answer: Came to my senses. CRABTREE Walter Gaskell isn't going to send James Leer to jail, Crabs. I know that.

question: Do you know he won't expel him?
answer: No. But I don't think that matters.

question: That's very enlightened, Professor. It's comforting to know that America's children have you for a teacher.
answer: Nobody teaches a writer anything. You tell them what you know. You tell them to find their voice and stick with it, because that's all you have in the end. You tell the ones who have it to keep at it and you tell the ones who don't to keep at it, too. Because that's the only way to get where you're going. Of course, it helps if you know where you want to go. Maybe that's the only thing--that and Sara-- that's made the last seven years worthwhile.

question: Me? What can I do?
answer: Gee, I don't know, Crabs... Improvise. You're good at that.

question: I'm sorry, Tripp.
answer: You peeked, didn't you?

question: I peeked. It really had the makings, Tripp. There was a lot to admire. I've ...never read anything quite like it.
answer: You're not just trying to make me feel better?

question: Scout's honor.
answer: Well, thanks for that, Crabs. Sara! Thanks, Q. I felt the same way about the bank teller's breasts in your last one.

question: Well, thanks for that, Crabs. Sara! Thanks, Q. I felt the same way about the bank teller's breasts in your last one.
answer: If you're looking for Hannah, she's on the aisle.

question: No...
answer: Who's that guy she's with? Didn't he used to be in workshop?

question: Sara! Yo, Traxler.
answer: Hey, Professor Tripp.

question: Do you get high, Sam?
answer: Only when I'm working. Holy shit. Are you serious?

question: As a heart attack.
answer: Thanks-Whoa, Professor Tripp, careful ^here...

question: Looking for you. I passed out.
answer: You did.

question: I've been doing that a lot lately.
answer: So I hear. You've also been smoking a lot of marijuana, I understand.

question: Do you think that's why I've been having these... ... spells?
answer: How long have you been having them?

question: The last month maybe.
answer: How long have you been smoking marijuana?

question: Spiro T. Agnew was vice president, I believe.
answer: That's probably not the problem, then. What about your lifestyle. Any major changes recently?

question: I've been trying to finish a book...
answer: And your wife left you.

question: Is that in my chart?
answer: I spoke with the woman who saved your life. You're lucky she came along when she did.

question: I know.
answer: You need to see a doctor, Mr. Tripp. An internist. And I think you really ought to consider seeing a therapist, as well.

question: She told you about. . .
answer: Her dog, yes.

question: Actually, it was her husband's dog...
answer: Look, Mr. Tripp. You have a drug problem, all right? On top of that, you have a bite on your ankle that is severely infected. We pumped you with antibiotics so you'll be fine, but another day or two and you might have lost the foot. As for your spells. I'm guessing they're a result of the anxiety you've been experiencing lately.

question: They're anxiety attacks? That's a little disappointing.
answer: Better luck next time.

question: So is my friend...is Sara still here?
answer: No. There's no one here.

question: I have to see her. As soon as possible.
answer: Look, Mr. Tripp. If you really want to leave, I can't stop you. But I'm going to write you a prescription for a course of ampicillin and I want you to follow it to the end-no matter how stupid you decide to be with everything else. All right?
